revision.text:
::[[File:Allergic Salute.JPG|thumb|Person demonstrating the Allergic Salute.]] The '''allergic salute''' (sometimes called the '''nasal salute''') is the characteristic and sometimes habitual gesture of wiping and/or rubbing the nose in an upwards or [[wikt:transverse|transverse]] manner with the fingers, palm, or back of the hand. It is termed a ''salute'' because the upward movement of the hand acts as an unintentional gesture.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Jim McMorran |author2=Damian Crowther |author3=Stew McMorran |author4=Steve Youngmin |author5=Ian Wacogne |author6=Jon Pleat |author7=Clive Prince |url=http://www.gpnotebook.co.uk/simplepage.cfm?ID=-1167392718 |title=allergic salute - General Practice Notebook |publisher=Gpnotebook.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}}</ref> The habit of using the hand to wipe the nose is observed more often in children but is common in adults as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/allergic+salute |title=Allergic Salute |publisher=Medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medicinetoday.com.au/2007/november/article/allergic-rhinitis-spring-action#.VNveDmTF8Yc |title=Allergic rhinitis: spring into action |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2015-02-11}}</ref> Saluting most commonly temporarily relieves nasal itching as well as removing small amounts of nasal mucus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acaai.org/allergist/Resources/ask-allergist/Pages/Ask_the_Allergist-What_Are_Allergic_Shiners.aspx |title=Ask the Allergist - What Are Allergic Shiners |publisher=Acaai.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}}</ref>
In people who are experiencing seizures, nose wiping has been observed as a semivoluntary action.<ref name= Fisher>{{Citation | last1 = Fisher | first1 = RS | last2 = Schachter | first2 = SC | title = The Postictal State: A Neglected Entity in the Management of Epilepsy. | journal = Epilepsy & Behavior | volume = 1 | pages = 52–59 | year = 2000 | doi = 10.1006/ebeh.2000.0023 | pmid = 12609127 | issue = 1 }}</ref>
==Process== The upwards wiping of the nose and nostrils allows for running mucus to be wiped off quickly and easily. Also, as the nostrils are being pushed up the air passages through the nose become temporarily propped open. This is especially beneficial if the air passages are swollen and the nostrils are itchy due to irritations such as [[allergic rhinitis]].<ref>{{cite web|author =N.J |url=http://my-health-inf.blogspot.com/2007/09/what-is-salute.html |title=What is an "Allergic Salute"? |publisher=My-health-inf.blogspot.com |date=2012-01-08 |accessdate=2012-11-25}}</ref>
The mucus that is wiped onto the hand will most likely carry bacteria and other germs which could then in turn be passed along to other people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.health.ny.gov/publications/7110/ |title=This is How Germs Spread... It's Sickening! |publisher=Health.ny.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}}</ref> Habitual as well as fast or rough saluting may also result in a crease (known as a [[transverse nasal crease]] or groove) running across the nose, and can lead to permanent physical deformity observable in childhood and adulthood.<ref name=pray221>{{cite book|last=Pray|first=W. Steven|title=Nonprescription Product Therapeutics|year=2005|publisher=[[Lippincott Williams & Wilkins]]|location=p. 221|isbn=0781734983}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livestrong.com/article/296252-white-line-on-nose-in-children/ |title=White Line On Nose In Children |publisher=Livestrong.Com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-25}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Eskimo kissing]] *[[Nose-picking]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Gestures}}
[[Category:Allergology]] [[Category:Euphemisms]] [[Category:Gestures]] [[Category:Habits]] [[Category:Nose]] [[Category:Rhinology]]

revision.text:
'''Aodh Ollabhar Ó Carrthoidh''' aka '''Aodh Ollbhar Ó Cárthaigh''', [[Gaels|Gaelic]]-[[Irish people|Irish]] poet, fl. mid-15th century.
==Overview==
[[Ó Cárthaigh]] was an [[Irish people|Irish]] poet who was active sometime in the middle years of the 15th century. His family were natives of [[Uí Maine]].
He is known from a single surviving poem,''Tosach féile fairsinge'', which survives in the following [[manuscripts]]:
* [[National Library of Scotland|NLS]] Adv 72/1/37 [[Book of the Dean of Lismore|Bk Dean Lism]]. first half of the 16th century * [[Royal Irish Academy|RIA]] 743 (A/iv/3) 17th century * RIA 785(23/G/8)[[Tadhg Ó Neachtain|T.ONeachtain]] et al.1711 * RIA3(23/L/17) S. OMurch.na R. 1744-5
It was published in 1938. It concerns the families of ''[[Mulrooney|Ó Maol Ruanaidh]] rí Céise'' and [[Mac Diarmata]] of [[Moylurg]]. It mentions ''Tomhaltach Mac Diarmuda/mac na ríoghna ó [[Rathcroghan|Ráith Chruachan]]'', and so may date from during or after Tomhaltach's lifetime. Rulers of Moylurg named Tomaltach were:
* [[Tomaltach na Cairge mac Diarmata]], ruled 1196-1207 * Tomaltach Cear mac Diarmata, 1331–1336 * Tomaltach an Einigh mac Diarmata, 1421–1458
The Bardic Poetry Database [http://bardic.celt.dias.ie/main.html] lists the subject of the poem as ''Tomaltach mc Conch.mhcAodha mhcCon MacDiarmada'', who died in 1458.
Other poems by Ó Cárthaigh may survive, but if so, are unattributed.
==See also==
* [[Muireadhach Ua Cárthaigh]] (died 1067) was Chief Poet of Connacht
==References==
* ''Dioghluim Dána'' Láimhbheartach Mac Cionnaith [[Lambert McKenna]] (ed), [[Dublin]], Oifig an tSoláthair [Government Publication Office], 1938, pp. 415–419 * ''The Surnames of Ireland'', [[Edward MacLysaght]], 1978
==External links== * http://bardic.celt.dias.ie/main.html * http://www.ucc.ie/celt/online/G402143/header.html * http://www.irishtimes.com/ancestor/surname/index.cfm?fuseaction=Go.&UserID=
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:O Carthaigh, Aodh Ollbhar}} [[Category:Medieval Irish poets]] [[Category:People from County Galway]] [[Category:People from County Roscommon]] [[Category:Year of death unknown]] [[Category:15th-century Irish poets]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Irish male poets]] [[Category:Irish-language writers]]

revision.text:
{{linguistics}} '''Dictema''' ({{lang-la|dico, dixi, dictum}} – "I say, I state") is an elementary situational-thematic unit of a text, formed of one or more sentences as units of the immediately lower level of language segments.<ref>[http://library.ua/m/articles/view/%D0%94%D0%98%D0%9A%D0%A2%D0%95%D0%9C%D0%90-%D0%92-%D0%A3%D0%A0%D0%9E%D0%92%D0%9D%D0%95%D0%92%D0%9E%D0%99-%D0%A1%D0%A2%D0%A0%D0%A3%D0%9A%D0%A2%D0%A3%D0%A0%D0%95-%D0%AF%D0%97%D0%AB%D0%9A%D0%90 ''Блох М. Я.'' Диктема в уровневой структуре языка // Вопросы языкознания. — М., 2000]</ref>
== History of creation == The concept of the dictema was put forward by [[Mark Bloch (linguist)|Mark Bloch]] in the mid-twentieth century in connection with a scientific discussion on the communicative units of language as described by [[Ferdinand de Saussure]] of the [[Geneva School]], as well as Professor Alexander Smirnitsky. In turn, Professor Bloch considered the level of language units that had gone unnoticed, namely the levels of the [[phoneme]] and [[morpheme]], to which he added the "third integral level of constructions with blurred boundaries" – syntax. Thus, following the creation of [[Morphology (linguistics)|morphology]] by [[Dionysius Thrax]] and [[syntax]] by [[Apollonius Dyscolus]], the isolation of the dictema represents another key stage in the history of [[grammar]].
== Structure == In a uniformly unfolding monologic written text, the dictema is usually represented by a paragraph, whereas in dialogical speech, the dictemma is usually represented by a rejoinder.<ref>''Ленская И. С.'' Проблема невербализованного содержания текста // Проблемы вербальной коммуникации и представления знаний. — Иркутск, 1998.</ref>
As an integrative unit of linguistic expression, the dictema distinguishes four main functionally significant aspects: naming, predication, thematization and stylization.
==See also== *[[Morphology (linguistics)|Morphology]] *[[Syntax]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Grammar| ]] [[Category:Linguistic units]]

revision.text:
{{About|the colloquial expression|the computer game|Egoboo (video game)}} {{wiktionary|egoboo}}
'''Egoboo''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|iː|g|oʊ|b|uː}} is a [[slang|colloquial expression]] for the [[pleasure]] received from [[reputation|public recognition]] of voluntary work.
The term was in use in [[science fiction fandom]] as early as 1947, when it was used (spelled "ego boo") in a letter from [[Rick Sneary]] published in the [[letter column]] of ''[[Thrilling Wonder Stories]]''.<ref>Sneary, Rick. "Letter" ''Thrilling Wonder Stories" June 1947]</ref> It was originally simply used to describe the "ego boost" someone feels on seeing their name in print. As a reliable way for someone to get their name in print was to do something worth mentioning, it became caught up with the idea of voluntary community participation. As a result of this, in later years, the term grew to mean something akin to an ephemeral [[currency]], e.g., "I got a lot of egoboo for editing that newsletter."
The term later spread into the [[open source programming]] [[Social movement |movement]], where the concept of non-monetary reward from community response is a key [[motivational|motivator]] for many of the participants.<ref name=esr>{{cite web|last=Raymond|first=Eric S.|title=The Social Context of Open-Source Software|url= http://catb.org/~esr/writings/homesteading/cathedral-bazaar/ar01s11.html|work=The Cathedral and the Bazaar|accessdate=21 November 2011}}</ref>
As a result of its prevalence in this context, it is often attributed to [[Eric S. Raymond]]. However, it has been in use in science fiction fandom since 1947 or earlier, being referenced in the 1959 collection of fandom-related jargon ''Fancyclopedia II''.<ref>[http://www.sff.net/people/diccon/CYINDEX.HTM Fancyclopedia II] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20011006033408/http://www.sff.net/people/diccon/cyindex.htm |date=2001-10-06 }} – index page</ref> It did not, however, occur in the 1944 predecessor to that work, ''Fancyclopedia I'',<ref>[http://fanac.org/Fannish_Reference_Works/Fancyclopedia/Fancyclopedia_I/#E Fancyclopedia I] – #E</ref> suggesting the term came into common use sometime in the intervening years. The first print citation available electronically is in a 1950 issue of [[Lee Hoffman]]'s ''Quandry'', where it is spelled "ego-boo";<ref>[http://fanac.org/fanzines/Quandry/Quandry5-12.jpeg Hoffman, Lee. "Presenting QUANDRY's neo-fan of the month" ''Quandry'' #5, p. 12]</ref> later usage dropped the hyphen and blended the two words, a common feature of fannish jargon.
The earliest online citation recorded is a reference to it being used in 1982, describing [[InConJunction]], a [[science fiction convention]] in [[Indiana]];<ref>[https://groups.google.com/group/net.sf-lovers/msg/988b7faf00af1308 net.sf-lovers] INCONJUNCTION II: AN SF CONVENTION</ref> the high proportion of science fiction fans on [[Usenet]], and the [[Internet]] generally, in early years no doubt helped spread it into the wider computing community.
==See also== *[[Amateur professionalism]] *[[Gratification]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Internet slang]] [[Category:Fanspeak]]

revision.comment: I've added an additional book where the elven language is used.
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=June 2012}} '''Elvish languages''' are [[constructed language]]s used by [[Elves in fantasy fiction and games|Elves]] in a [[fantasy]] setting. ==Tolkien's Elvish languages== {{main|Elvish languages (Middle-earth)}} Author [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] created many languages for his [[Elf (Middle-earth)|Elves]], which eventuated in the creation of a mythology (expounded in his books), complete with races, to speak the languages he had constructed. The language has quickly spread among modern day use, resulting in [[Quenya]] and [[Sindarin]] to become legally stated languages. His interest was primarily [[philology|philological]], and he said his stories grew out of his languages. The languages were the first thing Tolkien created for his mythos, starting with what he originally called "Qenya", the first primitive form of Elvish. This was later called [[Quenya]] (High-elven) and is one of the two most complete of Tolkien's languages (the other being [[Sindarin]], or Grey-elven). The phonology and grammar of Quenya are strongly influenced by [[Finnish language|Finnish]], [[Latin language|Latin]], [[Greek language|Greek]] and elements of ancient [[Germanic languages]], and Sindarin is strongly influenced by [[Welsh language|Welsh]]. {| class="wikitable" ! colspan = "7" | Internal history of Elvish languages |- | align="center" colspan="7" | '''Primitive Quendian'''
the tongue of all Elves at Cuiviénen |- | align="center" colspan="6" | '''Common Eldarin'''
the tongue of the Elves during the March | align="center" rowspan="3" | '''Avarin'''
combined languages of the Avari (at least six), some later merged with Nandorin |- | align="center" colspan="3" | '''Quenya'''
the language of the Ñoldor and the Vanyar | align="center" colspan="3" | '''Common Telerin'''
the early language of all the Lindar |- | align="center" | '''Quendya'''
also Vanyarin Quenya, daily tongue of the Vanyar | align="center" | '''Exilic Quenya'''
also Ñoldorin Quenya, colloquial speech of the Noldor | align="center" colspan="2" | '''Telerin'''
the language of the Teleri who reached the Undying Lands; a dialect of Quenya | align="center" | '''Sindarin'''
language of the Sindar | align="center" | '''Nandorin'''
languages of the Nandor, some were influenced by Avarin |} Tolkien conceived a family tree of Elvish languages, all descending from a common ancestor called [[Primitive Quendian]]. He worked extensively on how the languages diverged from Primitive Quendian over time, in phonology and grammar, in imitation of the development of real language families. In addition to Quenya and Sindarin, he sketched several other Elvish languages in far less detail, such as [[Telerin]], Nandorin, and Avarin. In addition to Tolkien's original lexicon, many fans have contributed words and phrases, attempting to create a language that can be fully used in reality.{{ME-ref|Solopova|"Invented Languages"}} ==Other Elvish languages== {{trivia|section|date=December 2017}} Since Tolkien, others have invented Elvish languages in their own fiction. Several borrow sounds and forms (or even whole words) from Tolkien's Elvish languages, especially Quenya, while others are quite distinct. *''Elvish,'' the language spoken in the book titled [https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40215820-elvish Elvish], by S.G. Prince. {{Cite book|title=Elvish|last=Prince|first=S.G.|publisher=|year=|isbn=1521435480|location=|pages=}} *''Elven'', the language of [[RuneScape]]'s Elves, is basically Welsh with a slight twist.{{clarification needed|date=May 2017}} *''The Ancient Language'' The language of the elves in [[The Inheritance Cycle]]. Also used by the riders and other magic users to cast spells. It was based on [[Old Norse]] and was the language of the now extinct Grey Folk. One cannot lie in the Ancient Language and is bound by what one says in it. *''Elven'', the language of the surface [[Elf (Dungeons & Dragons)|Elves]] of ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' (of which there are several dialects including ''Ssamath'' of the [[Drow (Dungeons & Dragons)|Drow]], which drow use in conjunction with Deep Speech). *''Ellylon'' and ''Hen Llinge'' (''Elder Speech'') - elvish languages of [[Andrzej Sapkowski]]'s ''[[The Witcher]]'' saga, based on [[Welsh language|Welsh]], [[Irish language|Irish]], [[French language|French]] and [[English language|English]]. *''Eltharin'', the language of the elves of [[Warhammer Fantasy (setting)|Warhammer Fantasy setting]]: **''Fan-Eltharin'', the language of the Wood Elves. **''Tar-Eltharin'', the language of the Sea Elves and High Elves **''Druhir'', the language of the Dark Elves *''[[Sperethiel]]'', The language of elves in [[Shadowrun]]. *Elvish language of [[Gael Baudino]]'s ''[[The Strands Series|Strands]]'' series, based on the [[Romance languages]]. *The Elvish language(s) of the [[Warcraft universe]] (Darnassian, Nazja, and Thalassian), are not described in detail but superficially resemble Tolkien's. Together, Darnassian, Nazja, and Thalassian are considered the modern elvish tongues of the Warcraft universe spoken by the modern Kaldorei, the Naga, and the highborne (respectively) while Elvish itself is considered an ancient tongue that is no longer used as a primary language. It is assumed that Elvish is the language from which Darnassian evolved; Darnassian then branched into Nazja, spoken underwater by the kaldorei that followed Queen Azshara after the sundering, and later on, Thalassian, which is spoken by the highborne as well as the Blood Elves. *"[[Gnommish]]" The language of the [[Artemis Fowl (series)|Artemis Fowl]] series, sometimes read in a spiral. *''Elvish'', the language of the Dalish elves in the ''[[Dragon Age]]'' series of videogames (and, to an extremely limited extent, the City Elves as well). *The Elves, or Mer, of the universe of [[The Elder Scrolls]], use various languages derived from ancient Ehlnofex. Such languages include Dunmeris, Pyandonean, Orcish (Orsimeris) and Bosmeris, among others. *The elves in the film ''[[Hellboy II: The Golden Army]]'' speak a language based on [[Old Irish]]. *''Shiväisith'' - language of the [[Elves (Marvel Comics)|Dark Elves]] in ''[[Thor: The Dark World]]'' constructed by [[David J. Peterson]]. *''Övüsi'' - The Elvish Language from [[Bright (film)|Bright]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.saunalahti.fi/alboin/tengwartutorial.htm Writing with Elvish fonts] * [https://www.jrrvf.com/hisweloke/sindar/online/english.html Sindarin Dictionary] {{Constructed languages}} [[Category:Elves in popular culture| ]] [[Category:Fictional languages]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{infobox biodatabase |title = Experimental Factor Ontology |logo = [[File:Logo of the Experimental Factor Ontlogy.gif|Logo of the Experimental Factor Ontlogy.gif]] |description = [[Ontology (information science)|Biomedical ontology]] |scope = Experimental and sample variables |organism = Multiple |center = [[European Molecular Biology Laboratory]] |laboratory = [[European Bioinformatics Institute]] |author = |released = |standard = |format = |url = [http://www.ebi.ac.uk/efo/ EFO] |citation = <ref name=pmid20200009>{{cite journal |pages=1112–8 |doi=10.1093/bioinformatics/btq099 |title=Modeling sample variables with an Experimental Factor Ontology |year=2010 |last1=Malone |first1=J. |last2=Holloway |first2=E. |last3=Adamusiak |first3=T. |last4=Kapushesky |first4=M. |last5=Zheng |first5=J. |last6=Kolesnikov |first6=N. |last7=Zhukova |first7=A. |last8=Brazma |first8=A. |last9=Parkinson |first9=H. |journal=Bioinformatics |volume=26 |pmid=20200009 |pmc=2853691 }}</ref> |download = [http://www.ebi.ac.uk/efo/efo.owl Download ontology] |sparql = [http://www.ebi.ac.uk/rdf/services/atlas/sparql EBI RDF Platform] |webapp = http://www.ebi.ac.uk/efo |standalone = |license = |versioning = |frequency = monthly |curation = Manually curated, text mining }}
'''Experimental factor ontology''', also known as '''EFO''', is an [[Open access (publishing)|open-access]] [[Ontology (information science)|ontology]] of [[Dependent and independent variables|experimental variables]] particularly those used in [[molecular biology]].<ref name=pmid20200009/> The ontology covers variables which include aspects of disease, [[anatomy]], [[cell type]], [[Immortalised cell line|cell lines]], [[chemical compound]]s and [[assay]] information. EFO is developed and maintained at the [[European Bioinformatics Institute|EMBL-EBI]] as a cross-cutting resource for the purposes of curation, querying and data integration<ref name=pmid24271396>{{cite journal |pages=D18-D25 |doi= 10.1093/nar/gkt1206 |title=The European Bioinformatics Institute's data resources 2014 |year=2014 |last1=Brooksbank|first1=C. |last2=Bergman |first2=M.T. |last3=Apweiler |first3=A. |last4=Birney |first4=E. |last5=Thornton |first5=J. = |journal=Nucleic Acids Research |volume=42 |pmid=24271396 |pmc=3964968 }}</ref> in resources such as [[Ensembl]],<ref name=ensembl2014>{{cite journal |pages=D749-D755 |doi=10.1093/nar/gkt1196 |title=Ensembl 2014| year=2014 |last1=Flicek |first1=P. |journal=Nucleic Acids Research |volume= 42|pmid=24316576 | pmc=3964975}}</ref> [[ChEMBL]] and Expression Atlas.<ref name=atlas>{{cite journal |pages=D690-D698 |doi=10.1093/nar/gkp936 |title=Gene Expression Atlas at the European Bioinformatics Institute| year=2010 |last1=Kapushesky|first1=M. | last2=Emam| first2=I | last3=Holloway| first3=E | last4=Kurnosov | first4=P| last5=Zorin|first5=A|last6=Malone | first6=J | last7=Rustici| first7=G |last8=Williams| first8=E |last9=Parkinson| first9=H |last10=Brazma| first10=A | journal=Nucleic Acids Research |volume=38 |pmid=19906730 | pmc=2808905}}</ref>
==Scope and access== The original aim of EFO was to describe experimental variables in the EBI's Expression Atlas resource.<ref name=pmid20200009/><ref name=atlas/> This consisted primarily of disease, anatomical regions and cell types. By December 2013 the scope had grown to include several other EMBL-EBI resources and several external projects including CellFinder,<ref name=cellfinder>{{cite journal | title=CELDA – an ontology for the comprehensive representation of cells in complex systems | pages=228 | volume=14 | journal=BMC Bioinformatics| last1=Seltmann |first1=S. | year=2014 | doi=10.1186/1471-2105-14-228 | pmid=23865855 | pmc=3722091}}</ref> cell lines from the [[ENCODE]] project and phenotype to SNP information in the [[National Human Genome Research Institute|NHGRI's]] [[Genome-wide association study|Catalog of Published Genome-Wide Association Studies]].<ref name=gwascat>{{cite journal |pages=D1001-D1006 |doi=10.1093/nar/gkt1229 |title=The NHGRI GWAS Catalog, a curated resource of SNP-trait associations| year=2014 |last1=Welter |first1=D. |journal=Nucleic Acids Research |volume=42 |pmid=24316577 | pmc=3965119}}</ref>
EFO makes use of existing biomedical ontologies from the [[Open Biomedical Ontologies]] collection in order to improve interoperability with other resources which may also use these same ontologies, such as [[ChEBI]]<ref name=pmid19854951>{{cite journal |pages=D249–54 |doi=10.1093/nar/gkp886 |title=Chemical Entities of Biological Interest: An update |year=2009 |last1=De Matos |first1=P. |last2=Alcantara |first2=R. |last3=Dekker |first3=A. |last4=Ennis |first4=M. |last5=Hastings |first5=J. |last6=Haug |first6=K. |last7=Spiteri |first7=I. |last8=Turner |first8=S. |last9=Steinbeck |first9=C. |journal=Nucleic Acids Research |volume=38 |pmid=19854951 |issue=Database issue |pmc=2808869 }}</ref> and the [[Ontology for Biomedical Investigations]].
All data in the database is non-proprietary or is derived from a non-proprietary source. It is thus freely accessible and available to anyone. In addition, each data item is fully traceable and explicitly referenced to the original source.
The EFO data is available through a public web interface, BioPortal Web Service hosted at the National Centre for Biomedical Ontology (NCBO)<ref name=BioPortal>{{cite web |url=http://bioportal.bioontology.org/ |title= NCBO BioPortal | publisher=Stanford University |accessdate=4 April 2014}}</ref> and downloads.
==See also== *[[European Molecular Biology Laboratory]] *[[Gene ontology]] *[[Open Biomedical Ontologies]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *http://www.ebi.ac.uk/efo/
{{DEFAULTSORT:EFO}} [[Category:Biological databases]] [[Category:Ontology (information science)]] [[Category:Biology terminology]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Faturānanda | honorific_suffix = | image = [[File:Faturananda.jpg|frame|center|Faturananda at Rourkela]] | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Rāmachandra Mishra | birth_date = {{Birth date|1915|06|01|df=y}} | birth_place = Jhānjirimangalā, [[Cuttack]], [[Odisha]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1995|11|06|1915|06|01}} | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | home_town = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | children = | parents = Bidyādhar Mishra
Subhadrā Mishra | relatives = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Rāmachandra Mishra''' (1 June 1915–6 November 1995), better known by his pen name '''Faturānanda''', is an [[Odia people|Odia]] [[humorism|humorous]] and [[satire|satirical]] writer. He is the founder of ''Sarasa Sāhitya Samiti''{{cite book|author=Alonzo Simpson McDaniel|title=The Absorption of Hydrocarbon Gases by Non-aqueous Liquids|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mq1mAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=6 June 2012|year=1990|publisher=University of Wisconsin--Madison}} Mishra has established "Kāntakabi Award" in the name of [[Laxmikānta Mohāpatra]]. His early life was spent in struggling which is the core part of his autobiography ''Mo phutā dangāra kāhāni''.{{cite book|author=Sāhitya Akademi|title=Indian literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c5JjAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=6 June 2012|year=1991|publisher=Sähitya Akademi.}} Mishra preferred "Phaturānanda" as a [[pen name]] in all his writings.{{cite book|title=Link|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KXBDAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=6 June 2012|year=1973|publisher=United India Periodicals}} Some of his popular writings include ''Nākatā Chitrakar'' (1953),{{cite book|author=Ganeswar Mishra|title=Voices against the stone: a brief survey of Oriya fiction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2GkuAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=6 June 2012|year=1981|publisher=Agradut}} ''Sāhi Mahābharat''.{{cite book|author1=Karuna Sagar Behera|author2=Jagannātha Paṭṭanāẏaka|author3=Harish Chandra Das|author4=Universe (Organization)|title=Cuttack, one thousand years|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wyxGAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=6 June 2012|year=1990|publisher=Cuttack City Millennium Celebrations Committee, The Universe}} His satirical writings in [[Odia language|Odia]] were based on political reality and prevailing cynicism.{{cite book|author=Sitakant Mahapatra|title=The curve of meaning: studies in Oriya literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t-vRAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=6 June 2012|year=1978|publisher=Image Publications}} == Early life == Mishra was born on 1 June 1915 at [[Jhānjirmangalā]], [[Cuttack]], [[Odisha]] to Bidyādhar Mishra and Subhadrā Mishra. == Literary career == Faturānanda is well known for his distinctly unique and original style of writing. He uses simple and colloquial language with a natural flow. Underlying theme in all his works is social issues addressed either directly or indirectly. According to Faturānanda “Stories I wrote initially were of tragic nature. After publication of “Dagaro” from Cuttack I started noticing the comic and humorous stories in it. Those were more or less of the same plot. For example, romance between a college boy and a college girl. Both decide to get married, but face some obstacle just before it. Finally the end of their romance. After seeing the same situation in all these published stories, I said – can’t there be any humor without these college boys and college girls. I made up my mind then and there not to ever include romance in my humor and satire. I have followed this principle ever since." == Awards and Recognitions == * Orissā Sāhitya Academy * Saralā Puraskār, Bhubaneswar * Jadumani Sāhitya Sansada, Nayāgada * Rādhānātha Pāthāgara, Sora, Bāleswar * Saralā Sāhitya Sansada, Cuttack * Utkal Pāthaka Sansada, Cuttack * Nāgarika Sambardhanā, Rourkela == Bibliography == === Autobiography === * ''Mo Phutā Dangāra Kāhāni'', 1989 === Novel === * ''Nākatā Chitrakar'', 1953 === Lyrical Poem === * ''Sāhi Mahābhārata'', 1987 === Story collections === * ''Heresā'', 1959 * ''Sāhitya Chāsa'', 1959 * ''Bidushaka'', 1963 * ''Mangalabāria Sāhitya Sansada'', 1963 * ''Hasakurā'', 1972 * ''Bruhat Bhānda'', 1977 * ''Amruta Behiā'', 1977 * ''Vote'', 1980 * ''Gamāt'', 1982 * ''Nidābehel'', 1982 * ''Sāhitya Beushana'', 1983 * ''Nabajiā'', 1983 * ''Thatalibāj'', 1983 * ''Sāhitya Bachābachi'', 1983 * ''Maskarā'', 1984 * ''Tāhuliā'' 1985 * ''Tāpuriā'', 1986 * ''Muchukundiā'', 1990 * ''Khilikhiliā'', 1993 * ''Odishāra Spin Bowler'', 1994 === Poetry === * ''Nilathā Kabi'', 1955 === Play === * ''Kalikati Chenka'', 1984 === Children's Literature === * ''Ajagabi Sikāra'' * ''Nālura Chandra Yātra'', 1991 === Translations === * ''Ādarsha Hindu Hotel'', 1977 - By Bibhutibhushana Chattopādyāya * ''Bhāratara Shrestha Hāsyagalpa'', 1980 - By Mujtabā Hossein === Other === * ''Famālochanā'', 1987 * ''Faturānandanka Dusprāpya Rachanā'', 1999 == References == {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Faturananda}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:Writers from Odisha]] [[Category:Odia-language writers]] [[Category:Indian satirists]] [[Category:Indian male writers]] [[Category:Indian humorists]]

revision.text:
{{for|literary works with the title ''Hypomnemata''|Hypomnemata (disambiguation)}}
'''Hypomnema''' (Greek. ὑπόμνημα, plural ὑπομνήματα, ''hypomnemata''), also spelled '''hupomnema''', is a [[Greek language|Greek]] word with several translations into English including a reminder, a note, a public record, a commentary, an anecdotal record, a draft, a copy, and other variations on those terms.<ref>([http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3D%23108803 Liddell and Scott Greek-English Lexicon online])</ref>
[[Plato]]'s theory of [[Anamnesis (philosophy)|anamnesis]] recognized the new status of [[writing]] as a device of artificial [[memory]], and he developed the hypomnesic principles for his students to follow in the [[Academy]]. According to Michel Foucault, "The hypomnemata constituted a material memory of things read, heard, or thought, thus offering these as an accumulated treasure for rereading and later [[meditation]]. They also formed a raw material for the writing of more systematic treatises in which were given arguments and means by which to struggle against some defect (such as anger, envy, gossip, flattery) or to overcome some difficult circumstance (a mourning, an exile, downfall, disgrace)."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Foucault|first1=Michel|title=Ethics: Subjectivity and Truth|date=1997|publisher=The New Press|location=New York|page=273}}</ref>
== Modern usage == [[Michel Foucault]] uses the word in the sense of "note", but his translators use the word "notebook", which is [[anachronism|anachronistic]] (see [[codex]] and [[wax tablet]]). Concerning [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca]]'s discipline of self-knowledge, Foucault writes: "In this period there was a culture of what could be called personal writing: taking notes on the reading, conversations, and reflections that one hears or engages in oneself; keeping kinds of [[notebook]]s on important subjects (what the Greeks call 'hupomnemata'), which must be reread from time to time so as to reactualize their contents."<ref>"The Hermeneutics of the Subject: Lectures at the College de France 1981-1982" Foucault, Michel, Picador, p. 500</ref> In an [http://foucault.info/documents/foucault.hypoMnemata.en.html excerpt from an ''Interview with Michel Foucault'' in ''The Foucault Reader''], he says: "As personal as they were, the hypomnemata must nevertheless not be taken for intimate diaries or for those accounts of spiritual experience (temptations, struggles, falls, and victories) which can be found in later [[Christian]] literature. [... T]heir objective is not to bring the arcana conscientiae to light, the confession of which—be it oral or written—has a purifying value."
==See also== * [[Commonplace book]] * [[Commentarii]] * [[Mnemonic]] * [[Silva rerum]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Concepts in the philosophy of language]]

revision.text:
[[ITU-T]] recommendation '''T.50''' specifies the '''International Reference Alphabet''' ('''IRA'''), formerly '''International Alphabet No. 5''' ('''IA5'''), a [[character encoding]]. [[ASCII]] is the U.S. variant of that character set.
The original version from November 1988 corresponds to [[ISO 646]]. The current version is from September 1992.
== History == At the beginning was the [[International Telegraph Alphabet No. 2]] ([[ITA2]]), a five bits code. IA5 is an improvement based on seven bits bytes.
*Recommendation V.3 IA5 (1968) Initial version, superseded<ref name="Salste_2016"/><ref name="ITU-CCITT_T50_1988"/> *Recommendation V.3 IA5 (1972) Superseded<ref name="Salste_2016"/><ref name="ITU-CCITT_T50_1988"/> *Recommendation V.3 IA5 (1976-10) Superseded *Recommendation V.3 IA5 (1980-11) Superseded *Recommendation T.50 IA5 (1984-10) Superseded<ref name="ITU-CCITT_T50_1988"/> *Recommendation T.50 IA5 (1988-11-25) Superseded<ref name="Salste_2016"/><ref name="ITU-CCITT_T50_1988">{{cite|title=International Alphabet No. 5 - Recommendation T.50 |publisher=[[International Telecommunication Union]] (ITU) - [[The International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee]] (CCITT) - Series T: Terminal Equipment and Protocols for Telematic Services |date=1993-04-16 |orig-year=1988-11-25 |id=E 33116 |url=https://www.itu.int/rec/dologin_pub.asp?lang=e&id=T-REC-T.50-198811-S!!PDF-E&type=items |access-date=2017-03-18 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170319173615/https://www.itu.int/rec/dologin_pub.asp?lang=e&id=T-REC-T.50-198811-S%21%21PDF-E&type=items |archive-date=2017-03-19 |df= }}</ref> *Recommendation T.50 IRA (1992-09-18) In force<ref name="Salste_2016">{{cite web |title=7-bit character sets: Revisions of ASCII |author-first=Tuomas |author-last=Salste |publisher=Aivosto Oy |date=January 2016 |id={{URN|nbn|fi-fe201201011004}} |url=http://www.aivosto.com/vbtips/charsets-7bit.html#body |access-date=2016-06-13 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160613145224/http://www.aivosto.com/vbtips/charsets-7bit.html#body |archive-date=2016-06-13}}</ref><ref name="ITU-CCITT_T50_1993">{{cite|title=International Reference Alphabet (IRA) - Information Technology - 7-bit Coded Character Set For Information Interchange - Recommendation T.50 |publisher=[[International Telecommunication Union]] (ITU) - [[The International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee]] (CCITT) - Terminal Equipment and Protocols for Telematic Services |date=1993-04-16 |orig-year=1992-09-18 |id=E 3177 |url=https://www.itu.int/rec/recommendation.asp?lang=en&parent=T-REC-T.50-199209-I |access-date=2017-03-18 |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141219040010/https://www.itu.int/rec/dologin_pub.asp?lang=e&id=T-REC-T.50-199209-I%21%21PDF-E&type=items |archive-date=2014-12-19 |df= }}</ref>
== Use == This standard is referenced by other standards such as RFC 3966.
It is also used by some [[analog modem]]s such as Cisco ones.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/routers/access/modem/AT/wic/command/reference/atwic2.html |title=AT Command Set and Register Summary for NM-8AM-V2, NM-16AM-V2, WIC-1AM, and WIC-2AM Analog Modem WAN Interface Cards - 2: Syntax and Procedures [Cisco 3600 Series Multiservice Platforms] - Cisco Systems |publisher=Cisco.com |access-date=2012-10-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907024347/http://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/routers/access/modem/AT/wic/command/reference/atwic2.html |archivedate=2011-09-07 |df= }}</ref>
This standard is referenced by other standards such as RFC 3939 - Calling Line Identification for Voice Mail Messages.
== Standardisation == * Identical standard: ISO 646:1991 (Twinned)
== See also == *[[ITU T.51]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-T.50/en Official ITU-T T.50 page] * [http://www.zytrax.com/tech/ia5.html Tech Info - Character Codes (IA5 and ISO 646)]
[[Category:ITU-T recommendations|T.50]] [[Category:Character encoding]] [[Category:Character sets]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox language | name = Irish Sign Language | nativename = Teanga Chomharthaíochta na hÉireann | pronunciation = ˈaɪərɪʃ saɪn ˈlæŋgwɪʤ | states = [[Republic of Ireland]], [[Northern Ireland]] | speakers = 5,000 deaf | date = 2014 | ref = e18 | speakers2 = 45,000 hearing signers | familycolor = Sign | fam1 = [[French Sign Language family|French Sign]] | nation = [[Republic of Ireland]] | iso3 = isg | glotto = iris1235 | glottorefname = Irish Sign Language }} [[Image:Irish Sign Language ABC's.png|thumb|250px|The ISL Manual/Fingerspelling Alphabet.]]
'''Irish Sign Language''' ('''ISL''', {{lang-ga|Teanga Chomharthaíochta na hÉireann}}) is the [[sign language]] of [[Ireland]], used primarily in the [[Republic of Ireland]]. It is also used in [[Northern Ireland]], alongside [[British Sign Language]] (BSL). Irish Sign Language is more closely related to [[French Sign Language]] (LSF) than to [[British Sign Language|BSL]], though it has influence from both languages. It has influenced sign languages in Australia and South Africa, and has little relation to either spoken [[Irish language|Irish]] or [[English language|English]].
==Development== The [[Irish Deaf Society]] says that ISL "arose from within deaf communities", "was developed by deaf people themselves" and "has been in existence for hundreds of years". According to [[Ethnologue]], the language has influence from both LSF and BSL, as well as from [[signed French]] and [[signed English]], BSL having been introduced in Dublin in 1816.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=isg|title=Irish Sign Language|website=Ethnologue.com|accessdate=15 January 2018}}</ref> The first school for deaf children in Ireland was established in 1816 by [[Charles Orpen|Dr. Charles Orpen]]. The Claremont Institute was a [[Protestant]] institution and given that Ireland was a part of the United Kingdom, it is no surprise that BSL (or some version of [[signed English]] based in BSL) was used for teaching and learning (Pollard 2006). McDonnell (1979) reports that the Irish institutions - [[Roman Catholic|Catholic]] and Protestant - did not teach the children to speak and it was not until 1887 that Claremont report changing from a manual to an [[oralism|oral approach]]. For the Catholic schools, the shift to oralism came later: St. Mary's School for Deaf Girls moved to an oral approach in 1946 and St. Joseph's School for Deaf Boys shifted to oralism in 1956,<ref>Griffey 1994, Crean 1997</ref> though this did not become formal state policy until 1972. Sign language use was seriously suppressed and religion was used to further stigmatise the language (e.g. children were encouraged to give up signing for [[Lent]] and sent to [[sacrament of Reconciliation|confession]] if caught signing).<ref>McDonnell and Saunders 1993</ref> The fact that the Catholic schools are segregated on the basis of gender led to the development of a gendered-generational variant of Irish Sign Language that is still evident (albeit to a lesser degree) today.<ref>LeMaster 1990, Leeson and Grehan 2004, Leeson 2005, Leeson and Saeed 2012, Leonard 2005, Grehan 2008</ref>
ISL was brought by Catholic missionaries to [[Australia]],and to Scotland and England, with remnants of ISL still visible in some variants of BSL, especially in [[Glasgow]], and with some elderly [[Auslan]] Catholics still using ISL today. In South Africa, the Dominican nuns who established Catholic Schools saw a need for a school for the deaf, but due to resource constraints were not in a position to do this immediately. Instead, they wrote back to their Mother House in Cabra requesting an experienced teacher of the deaf. A deaf teacher, Ms. Bridget Lynne, responded. Remnants of gendered generational Irish Sign Language are thought to still be visible in some dialects of South African Sign Language<ref>{{Cite book|title=Irish Sign Language|last=Leeson|first=Lorraine|last2=Saeed|first2=John I.|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|year=2012|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>, which can probably be traced back to Ms. Lynne.
==Oireachtas bill== The "Recognition of Irish Sign Language for the Deaf Community Bill 2016" passed all stages in the [[Oireachtas]] (Irish Parliament) on 14 December 2017, and was signed into law by the [[President of Ireland]] [[Michael D. Higgins|Michael D Higgins]] on 24 December 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/irish-sign-language-given-official-legal-recognition-1.3338081|title=Irish Sign Language given official legal recognition|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/ireland/2017/1224/929482-sign-language-bill/|title=President signs Irish Sign Language bill into law|date=2017-12-24|work=RTE.ie|access-date=2018-01-16|language=en}}</ref> The Bill ensures that public services are available through ISL and also outlines the need for greater access to education through sign language. Prior to the passage, there was no automatic right for deaf people to have an ISL [[Language interpretation|interpreter]] (except for criminal court proceedings). For the deaf community, recognition of ISL means more legal rights and better access to [[Public service|public services]] - including [[Education in the Republic of Ireland|education]], [[Healthcare in the Republic of Ireland|healthcare]], [[Media of the Republic of Ireland|media]] and [[banking]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/2017/1213/927259-irish-sign-language/|title=Dáil passes 'historic' sign language legislation|date=2017-12-14|work=RTE.ie|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/irish-sign-language-set-to-be-given-official-status-36407921.html|title=Irish Sign Language set to be given official status - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-12-14|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/irish-sign-language-set-to-receive-official-recognition-818648.html|title=Irish sign language set to receive official recognition|date=2017-12-14|work=Breaking News|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref>
==Language code== The [[ISO 639-3]] code for Irish Sign Language is 'isg'; 'isl' is the code for [[Icelandic language|Icelandic]].
==See also== *[[Irish manual alphabet]] *[[Auslan|Australian Sign Language]] *[[Northern Ireland Sign Language]] *[[South African Sign Language]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== * Crean, E, J. (1997): ''Breaking the silence: The education of the deaf in Ireland 1816-1996''. Dublin: Irish Deaf Society Publication. * Department of Education (1972): ''The Education of Children who are Handicapped by Impaired Hearing''. Dublin: Government Publications. * Grehan, C. (2008): ''Communication Islands: The Impact of Segregation on Attitudes to ISL among a Sample of Graduates of St. Mary's School for Deaf Girls''. Unpublished M.Phil dissertation. School of Linguistic, Speech and Communication Sciences. Dublin: Trinity College. * Griffey, N. (1994): ''From Silence to Speech: Fifty years with the Deaf''. Dublin: Dominican Publications. * Leeson, L. (2005). Vying with Variation: Interpreting Language Contact, Gender Variation and Generational Difference. In T. Janzen (ed.) Topics in Signed Language Interpreting. Amsterdam and Philadelphia: John Benjamins. 251-292. *Leeson, L. and C. Grehan (2004): "To The Lexicon and Beyond: The Effect of Gender on Variation in Irish Sign Language". In Van Herreweghe, Mieke and Myriam Vermeerbergen (eds.): ''To the Lexicon and Beyond: Sociolinguistics in European Deaf Communities''. Washington DC: Gallaudet University Press. 39-73. * Leeson, L. and J. I. Saeed (2012) Irish Sign Language. Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press. * LeMaster, B. (1990): ''The Maintenance and Loss of Female and Male Signs in the Dublin Deaf Community''. Ann Arbor: U.M.I .: University of California, Los Angeles Dissertation. * Leonard, C. (2005): "Signs of diversity: use and recognition of gendered signs among your Irish Deaf people". In: ''Deaf Worlds'' 21:2. 62-77. * McDonnell, P. (1979): ''The Establishment and Operation of Institutions for the Education of the Deaf in Ireland, 1816-1889''. Unpublished essay submitted in part-fulfillment of the requirements of the award of the degree of Master in Education. Dublin: University College Dublin. * McDonnell, P. and Saunders, H. (1993): "Sit on Your Hands: Strategies to Prevent Signing". In Fischer, R. and Lane, H. (eds.) ''Looking Back: A Reader on the History of Deaf Communities and their Sign Languages''. Hamburg: Signum. 255-260. * Pollard, Rachel (2006): ''The Avenue''. Dublin: Denzille Press. * Rose, Heath and John Bosco Conama. 2018. Linguistic imperialism: still a valid construct in relation to language policy for Irish Sign Language. ''Language Policy'' Volume 17, Issue 3, pp 385–404.
==External links== *[http://www.irishdeafsociety.ie Irish Deaf Society] *[http://www.tcd.ie/slscs/cds Centre for Deaf Studies, TCD]

revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name = Kaingang |nativename = kanhgág |states = [[Brazil]] |region = [[São Paulo]], [[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]], [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]], [[Rio Grande do Sul]] |ethnicity = [[Kaingang people]] |speakers = 18,000 |date=1989 |ref=e18 |familycolor = American |fam1 = [[Macro-Jê languages|Macro-Gê]] |fam2 = [[Jê languages|Gê]] |fam3 = Southern |lc1 = kgp |ld1 = Kaingang |lc2 = zkp |ld2 = São Paulo Kaingáng |linglist=qr7 |lingname=Wayaná (Guayaná) |glotto=kain1271 |glottorefname=Kaingangic }} The '''Kaingang language''' (also spelled '''Kaingáng''') is a [[Gê languages|Gê language]] spoken by the [[Kaingang]] people of southern [[Brazil]].{{cite book |last = Rodrigues |first = Aryon Dall'Igna |authorlink = Aryon Rodrigues |title = Línguas brasileiras. Para o conhecimento das línguas indígenas |year = 1986 |publisher = Ed. Loyola |location = São Paulo |language = Portuguese }} The Kaingang nation has about 30,000  people, and about from 60% to 65% speak the language. Most also speak [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]. The Kaingang and Xokleng were previously considered a single ethnicity, which went by a number of names, including ''Amhó, Dorin, Gualachi, Chiqui, Ingain, Botocudo, Ivitorocái (= Amho), Kamé, Kayurukré, Tain (= Ingain), Taven.'' Some of these may have been tribal names; others were exonyms. Those living along the coast at the time of the Conquest were called ''Guayaná'', and are considered to be the ancestors of the Kaingang.''Enciclopédia dos Povos Indígenas no Brasil - Instituto Socioambiental'' It is unknown to what extent the names might have corresponded to dialectal differences. == Culture == The Kaingang language is classified as a member of the ''Ge'' family, the largest language family in the Macro-Ge stock. The Kaingang territory occupies the modern states of [[São Paulo]], [[Paraná (state)|Paraná]], [[Santa Catarina (state)|Santa Catarina]] and [[Rio Grande do Sul]] (and, until the beginning of the 20th century, [[Misiones Province|Misiones, Argentina]]). Today they live in around 30 indigenous lands (similar to Native American [[Indian reservation|reservations]]), especially at Rio Grande do Sul and Paraná. In the 1960s, because of a missionary interest (conducted by the [[Summer Institute of Linguistics]] (SIL)), the language was studied by Ursula Wiesemann.{{cite book |last = Wiesemann |first = Ursula |title = Die phonologische und grammatische Struktur der Kaingáng-Sprache |year = 1972 |publisher = Mouton |location = The Hague |language = German }} == Phonology == ===Consonants=== A large number of allophones map to a set of 14 phonemes:Jolkesky, M. P. V. (2009). [http://www.iel.unicamp.br/revista/index.php/seta/article/view/557/474 Fonologia e prosódia do Kaingáng falado em Cacique Doble] (RS). Anais do XIV SETA - Seminário de Teses em Andamento, 3:675-685. Campinas: Editora do IEL-UNICAMP. [http://sites.google.com/site/marcelojolkesky/fpkcd-anexo.pdf (anexo)] {| class="wikitable" style=text-align:center |-style="font-size: 90%;" ! !colspan=2| [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] !colspan=2| [[Dental consonant|Dental]]/
[[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] !colspan=2| [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] !colspan=2| [[Velar consonant|Velar]] !colspan=2| [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! [[Stop consonant|Stop]] |width=20px style="border-right: 0;"|{{IPAlink|p}}||width=20px style="border-left: 0;"|{{IPAlink|m}}~{{IPAlink|b}} |width=20px style="border-right: 0;"|{{IPAlink|t}}||width=20px style="border-left: 0;"|{{IPAlink|n}}~{{IPAlink|d}} |width=20px style="border-right: 0;"| ||width=20px style="border-left: 0;"|{{IPAlink|ɲ}}~{{IPAlink|ɟ}} |width=20px style="border-right: 0;"|{{IPAlink|k}}||width=20px style="border-left: 0;"|{{IPAlink|ŋ}}~{{IPAlink|g}} |width=20px style="border-right: 0;"|{{IPAlink|ʔ}}||width=20px style="border-left: 0;"| |- ! [[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] |style="border-right: 0;"|{{IPAlink|ɸ}}||style="border-left: 0;"| |colspan=2| |style="border-right: 0;"|{{IPAlink|ç}}||style="border-left: 0;"| |colspan=2| |rowspan=2 style="border-right: 0;"|{{IPAlink|h}}||rowspan=2 style="border-left: 0;"| |- ! [[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] |style="border-right: 0;"| ||style="border-left: 0;"|{{IPAlink|w}} |style="border-right: 0;"| ||style="border-left: 0;"|{{IPAlink|ɹ}} |style="border-right: 0;"| ||style="border-left: 0;"|{{IPAlink|j}} |colspan=2| |} All consonants have varying [[allophone]]s depending on their position in the word and on the adjancency of nasal vowels: * The [[Oral consonant|oral]] stops have [[Prenasalized stop|prenasalized]] allophones {{IPA|[ᵐp, ⁿt, ᵑk]}} when following a nasal vowel. In unstressed syllables, {{IPA|/k/}} is furthermore voiced to become {{IPA|[ᵑɡ]}}. * The [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|/ʔ/}} and the non-stop consonants are realized as nasalized {{IPA|[ʔ̃, ɸ̃, ç̃, h̃, w̃, ɹ̃, j̃]}} preceding nasal vowels. * The phonemes {{IPA|/b, d, ɟ, ɡ/}} are only realized as voiced oral stops between two oral vowels. They are realized as voiced prenasalized stops {{IPA|[ᵐb, ⁿd, ᶮɟ, ᵑɡ]}} when between a nasal and an oral vowel, as well as word-initially before oral vowels. Between an oral and a nasal vowel they are conversely realized as [[Prestopped consonant|prestopped]] {{IPA|[ᵇm, ᵈn, ᶡɲ, ᶢŋ]}}. Between two nasal vowels, or word-initially before nasal vowels, they are realized as full nasal stops: {{IPA|[m, n, ɲ, ŋ]}}. The first two types of realization also apply when occurring in the syllable coda and followed by a non-nasal segment; these voiced/prenasalized will however be additionally [[Unreleased stop|unreleased]]: {{IPA|[⁽ᵐ⁾b˺, ⁽ⁿ⁾d˺, ⁽ᶮ⁾ɟ˺, ⁽ᵑ⁾ɡ˺]}}. However, by convention these stop-phonemes are always written as in the orthography. * When preceded by an oral vowel, the sequences {{IPA|/nt, ɲt, ŋk/}} can be realized as geminate stops: {{IPA|[tː, cː, kː]}}. * {{IPA|/ŋ/}} is optionally labialized: {{IPA|[ɡʷ, ŋʷ]}}, etc. * The non-glottal fricatives can word-initially be [[Free variation|optionally]] realized as affricates {{IPA|[p͡ɸ, c͡ç]}} (including their nasal allophones: {{IPA|[p͡ɸ̃, c͡ç̃]}}.) * {{IPA|/w/}} can optionally be realized as a voiced bilabial fricative {{IPA|[β]}}, and {{IPA|/j/}} as a voiced palatal stop {{IPA|[ɟ]}}. When nasalized, {{IPA|/j/}} varies between {{IPA|[j̃]}} and {{IPA|[ɲ]}}. * Word-initially, {{IPA|/ɹ/}} is preceded by an epenthetic {{IPA|[ə]}}; it is {{IPA|[ɾ]}} in tonic syllables and {{IPA|[l]}} in atonic syllables, and when nasalized, it varies between {{IPA|[ɾ̃]}} and {{IPA|[ɹ̃]}}. As a syllable coda it is a flap when oral and approximant when nasal, and may optionally be palatalized: {{IPA|[ɾʲ], [ɹ̃ᶮ]}}. * Word-initially in a stressed syllable, {{IPA|/t/}} may vary in realization between [[dental consonant|dental]] {{IPA|[t̪]}} and [[alveolar consonant|alveolar]] {{IPA|[t]}}. Following palatal consonants or preceding a close vowel, it can also realized as a palatal stop, {{IPA|[c]}}. ===Vowels=== {| class="wikitable IPA" |- |+ Vowel phonemes of Kaingang{{sfnp|Jolkesky|2009|p=677}} !rowspan=2 colspan=2| ![[Front vowel|Front]] !colspan=2|[[Back vowel|Back]] |- !{{small|unrounded}} !{{small|unrounded}} !{{small|rounded}} |-align=center !rowspan=2|[[Close vowel|Close]] !{{small|oral}} | {{IPA link|i}} | | {{IPA link|u}} |-align=center !{{small|[[Nasal vowel|nasal]]}} | {{IPA link|ĩ}} | | {{IPA link|ũ}} |-align=center ![[Close-mid vowel|Close-mid]] !rowspan=2|{{small|oral}} | {{IPA link|e}} | {{IPA link|ɤ}} | {{IPA link|o}} |-align=center !rowspan=2|[[Open-mid vowel|Open-mid]] | {{IPA link|ɛ}} | {{IPA link|ʌ}} | {{IPA link|ɔ}} |-align=center !{{small|nasal}} | {{IPA link|ɛ̃}} | {{IPA link|ʌ̃}} | {{IPA link|ɔ̃}} |-align=center ![[Open vowel|Open]] !{{small|oral}} | | {{IPA link|ɑ}} | |} * Atonic {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/e/}} as well as {{IPA|/u/}} and {{IPA|/o/}} are merged; the former pair to {{IPAblink|ɪ}}, the latter pair to {{IPAblink|ʊ}}.{{sfnp|Jolkesky|2009|pp=676 and 682}} * The backness of the unrounded back vowels {{IPA|/ɤ, ʌ, ɑ/}} varies between back {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ɤ}}, {{IPA link|ʌ}}, {{IPA link|ɑ}}]}} and central {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ɘ}}, {{IPA link|ɜ}}, {{IPA link|ɐ}}]}}.{{sfnp|Jolkesky|2009|pp=676 and 682}} * All of the oral vowels {{IPA|/i, u, e, ɤ, o, ɛ, ʌ, ɔ, ɑ/}} can be realized as voiceless {{IPA|[i̥, u̥, e̥, ɤ̥ ~ ɘ̥, o̥, ɛ̥, ʌ̥ ~ ɜ̥, ɔ̥, ɑ̥ ~ ɐ̥]}}.{{sfnp|Jolkesky|2009|p=676}}{{fix|text=in which environments?|date=July 2015}} * Nasal vowels have the same quality as oral vowels. However, {{Harvcoltxt|Jolkesky|2009}} doesn't list a central variant of {{IPA|/ʌ̃/}} on his phone chart.{{sfnp|Jolkesky|2009|pp=676 and 682}} == Orthography == Wiesemann proposed an alphabet for the language, which is still in use despite some problems.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} It is based on the [[Latin script]], and consists of fourteen consonants and fourteen vowels, matching the fourteen consonants and fourteen vowels of the Kaingang language. {| class="wikitable IPA" |- !colspan=2|Vowels!!colspan=2|Consonants |- !Letter!!Sound !Letter!!Sound |- |a||ɑ |f||ɸ |- |á||ʌ |g||ŋ~ɡ |- |ã||ɔ̃ |h||h |- |e||e |j||j |- |é||ɛ |k||k |- |ẽ||ɛ̃ |m||m~b |- |i||i |n||n~d |- |ĩ||ĩ |nh||ɲ~ɟ |- |o||o |p||p |- |ó||ɔ |r||ɹ |- |u||u |s||ç |- |ũ||ũ |t||t |- |y||ɤ |v||w |- |ỹ||ʌ̃ |'||ʔ |} There are dictionaries and grammars available for Kaingang. A school was set up in 1969 to teach the Kaingang people to read and write their language. However, the school produced many Kaingang speakers who went back to their reservations to teach others and spread the writing innovations they learned. Only one of the dialects is used as the standard written form, though having the writing system provided a source of pride in the language for the Kaingang people. A Kaingang bible has been published, as well as a dictionary and other publications. Examples of Kaingang writing can be found on [http://www.omniglot.com/writing/kaingang.php Omniglot]. ==Grammar== ===Postpositions=== Kaingang makes use of [[postpositions]]. * '''goj:''' water * '''goj ki:''' in the water Postpositions are also used to mark subject. * '''Mĩg vỹ venhvó tĩ.''' The jaguar runs. * '''Kofá tóg pỹn tãnh.''' The old man killed the snake. ===Verbs=== Kaingang verbs do not inflect. * '''rãgró:''' to plant * '''Ti tóg rãgró krãn huri.''' He planted beans. * '''Ẽg tóg rãgró krãn huri.''' We planted beans. == References == {{reflist}} == Bibliography == {{refbegin}} * {{citation |last=D'Angelis |first=Wilmar R. |title=Traços de modo e modos de traçar geometrias: línguas Macro-Jê & teoria fonológica |series=Tese de Doutorado, 2 vols. |year=1998 |publisher=IEL-Unicamp |location=Campinas, Brazil |language=Portuguese }} * {{citation |last=Jolkesky |first=Marcelo Pinho de Valhery |year=2009 |title=Fonologia e prosódia do Kaingáng falado em Cacique Doble |journal=Anais do SETA |volume=3 |pages=675–685 |place=Campinas |publisher=Editora do IEL-UNICAMP |url=http://www.iel.unicamp.br/revista/index.php/seta/article/view/557/474 }} {{refend}} == External links == {{Incubator|code=kgp}} * [http://www.etnolinguistica.org/lingua:kaingang Catálogo de Línguas Sul-Americanas: Kaingáng] * [http://www.portalkaingang.org Portal Kaingang] * [http://libdigi.unicamp.br/document/?code=vtls000127555 Kaingang phonology and Macro-Ge languages] * [http://paginas.terra.com.br/educacao/GICLI/Kaingang.pdf Comparison of English and Kaingang phrases]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * Jolkesky, M. P. V. (2006a). [http://sites.google.com/site/marcelojolkesky/Silogismos.pdf Língua, lexicografia e os SILogismos em Kaingang - Português Dicionário Bilingüe. ] (manuscrito) * Jolkesky, M. P. V. (2006b). [http://sites.google.com/site/marcelojolkesky/semi%C3%B3tica.pdf Análise semiótica de um texto Kaingáng. ] (manuscrito) * Jolkesky, M. P. V.; Santos, L. C. (2008). [http://sites.google.com/site/marcelojolkesky/relativas.pdf Construções relativas restritivas em Kaingáng. ] Em: S. Telles & A. S. de Paula (orgs.) Topicalizando Macro-Jê, 247-260. Recife: NECTAR. {{Languages of Brazil}} {{Macro-Jê languages}} [[Category:Analytic languages]] [[Category:Indigenous languages of the Americas]] [[Category:Isolating languages]] [[Category:Jê languages]] [[Category:Languages of Brazil]]

'''Kali''' is a presumably moribund [[Mbum languages|Mbum]] language of northern [[Cameroon]] or the [[Central African Republic]].

revision.comment: canada, not canadian people using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''Language Proficiency Index''' or '''LPI''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[standardized test]] for [[English language|English]] [[language proficiency|proficiency]] and is administered by Paragon Testing Enterprises, a subsidiary of the University of British Columbia. The results of this test are used mostly by post secondary institutions and professional organizations within the Province of [[British Columbia]], Alberta and in the territory of [[Yukon]].
The test is 2.5 hours long and consists of five components, Parts I and II are multiple choice and deal with catching various grammar-related mistakes. Part III is a reading-comprehension section, also in multiple choice. Part IV deals with writing brief summaries of a short piece of writing and Part V is a 300-400 word argumentative essay.
==External links== *[http://www.lpitest.ca/ Language Proficiency Index (LPI) Homepage] *[http://www.lpitest.ca/about/test-scoring/ Test Scoring]
[[Category:Education in British Columbia]]
{{lang-stub}}

revision.comment: removed links from lead citation per [[WP:SCOTUS/SG]]; citation tweaks
revision.text:
{{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=Lau v. Nichols |ArgueDate=December 10 |ArgueYear=1973 |DecideDate=January 21 |DecideYear=1974 |FullName=Lau, et al. v. Nichols, et al. ( Alan Nichols- President of the school board) |USVol=414 |USPage=563 |ParallelCitations=94 S. Ct. 786; 39 [[L. Ed. 2d]] 1; 1974 [[U.S. LEXIS]] 151 |Prior=Certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit |Subsequent= |Holding= |SCOTUS=1972-1975 |Majority=Douglas |JoinMajority=Brennan, Marshall, Powell, Rehnquist |Concurrence=Stewart |JoinConcurrence=Burger, Blackmun |Concurrence2=White |Concurrence3=Blackmun |JoinConcurrence3=Burger |LawsApplied=[[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] }} '''''Lau v. Nichols''''', 414 U.S. 563 (1974), was a [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] case in which the Court unanimously decided that the lack of supplemental language instruction in public school for students with [[limited English proficiency]] violated the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]]. The court held that since non-English speakers were denied a meaningful education, the [[disparate impact]] caused by the school policy violated the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the school district was demanded to provide students with "appropriate relief".<ref name=":1">{{ussc|name=Lau v. Nichols|volume=414|page=563|pin=|year=1974}}.</ref>
== Background == In 1971, the San Francisco school system desegregated based on the result of Supreme Court case ''[[Guey Heung Lee v. Johnson|Lee v. Johnson]].'' 2856 Chinese students, who were not fluent in English, were integrated back into the [[San Francisco Unified School District]] (SFUSD). Only about 1000 of those students were provided supplemental English instruction. Of the other 1800-plus Chinese students who weren't fluent in English, many were placed in special education classes while some were forced to be in the same grade for years.<ref name=":1" />
Even though the [[Bilingual Education Act]] was passed by Congress in 1968 to address the needs of Limited English Speaking Abilities students, the funding was limited.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Punches|first=Michael W.|date=1985-01-01|title=The Shaping of a Social Policy: The Bilingual Education Act, 1968-1984|jstor=42589123|journal=Journal of Thought|volume=20|issue=4|pages=62–70}}</ref> School participation in those programs was also voluntary, and by 1972, "only 100,391 students nationally, out of approximately 5,000,000 in need were enrolled in a [[Title VII]]-funded program."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Petrzela|first=Natalia M|year=2010|title=Before the Federal Bilingual Education Act: Legislation and Lived Experience in California|url=|journal=Peabody Journal of Education|volume=85|pages=414|via=}}</ref>
Edward H. Steinman, a public-interest lawyer, reached out to the parents of Kinney Kinmon Lau and other Chinese students with limited English proficiency. He encouraged them to challenge the school district, and they filed a class action suit against [[Alan Nichols|Alan H. Nichols]], the president of the SFUSD at the time, and other officials in the school district.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/1984/01/25/05300020.h03.html|title=Languages, Law, and San Francisco - Education Week|date=1984-01-25|newspaper=Education Week|access-date=2016-12-09}}</ref> The students claimed that they were not receiving special help in school due to their inability to speak English, and they argued they were entitled to special help under the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]] and the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] because of equal protection and the ban on educational discrimination.<ref name=":1" />
The [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|District Court for the Northern District of California]] denied the relief and the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit|Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] affirmed the decision. The District Court argued that since a uniform policy was used for all students in SFUSD and that the district didn't intentionally discriminate against students with limited English proficiency, equal protection was provided and the Fourteenth Amendment was not violated. The Court of Appeals claimed that since the school district provided the same treatment for all students, even though some students were disadvantaged due to their limited fluency in English, the school district was not required to make up for the different starting points of students.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sugarman|first=Stephen D.|last2=Widess|first2=Ellen G.|date=1974-01-01|title=Equal Protection for Non-English-Speaking School Children: Lau v. Nichols|jstor=3479823|journal=California Law Review|volume=62|issue=1|pages=157–182|doi=10.2307/3479823}}</ref> The students appealed the Court of Appeal's decision to the Supreme Court.
== Decision of the Supreme Court == [[File:Justice_Blackmun_Official.jpg|left|thumb|245x245px|Justice Harry Blackmun, who concurred with the decision and stated that the number of students affected in this case was substantial enough to deem affirmative remedies necessary.]]
The Supreme Court issued its decision on January 21, 1974, with the Court unanimously ruling in favor of Lau. Instead of examining the equal protection clause from the 14th Amendment, the Court relied on Section 601 of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Since the school system received federal funding, it was required to provide equal opportunities and access to all students. The Court claimed that even though the school districts provided equal treatment for all students, it still imposed disparate impact on the non-English speaking students since they were not able to understand the class material as effectively as other students and therefore were deprived of having "meaningful" education. The Court also referenced the guideline established by [[Office for Civil Rights|the Office for Civil Rights]] (OCR) of [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|the Department of Health, Education and Welfare]] in 1970, which stated that language could be used as a proxy of discrimination on national origin and that "the district must take affirmative steps to rectify the language deficiency in order to open its instructional program to these students."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ocr/docs/lau1970.html|title=DHEW Memo Regarding Language Minority Children|date=2015-10-15|website=www2.ed.gov|language=en|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref> The Supreme Court demanded the school district to make necessary changes to provide equal education to the non-English speakers, but it didn't state any specific remedies for the district to follow.<ref name=":1" />
Justice [[Potter Stewart]], joined by Chief Justice [[Warren E. Burger|Burger]] and Justice [[Harry Blackmun|Blackmun]], concurred with this decision as he stated that affirmative remedial efforts, suggested by the OCR, were constitutional and appropriate in this case as long as the efforts were "reasonably related to the purposes of the enabling legislation." In his concurrence joined by Chief Justice Burger, Justice Blackmun also suggested that "numbers are at the heart of this case" and that if the case only involved a few students, rather than nearly 2,000, the decision would not be the same.<ref name=":1" />
== Legacy == Lau remains an important decision in bilingual education history. In this case, the Supreme Court found the violation of Civil Rights Act of 1964 based on the discriminatory effect of the school policy regardless of the intent of the officials. It prohibited the "sink and swim" policy and set a precedent of finding disparate impact in violation of the Civil Rights Act.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moran|first=Rachel F.|year=2005|title=Undone by Law: The Uncertain Legacy of Lau v. Nichols|url=|journal=Berkeley La Raza Law Journal|volume=16|pages=|via=}}</ref> The decision was subsequently followed by the passing of [[Equal Educational Opportunities Act of 1974]] in Congress, which specifically prohibited discrimination against faculty and student in public schools and required the school districts to take "appropriate action" to overcome the barriers to equal participation of all students.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=3776#axzz1pm57fScr|title=Richard Nixon: Special Message to the Congress on Equal Educational Opportunities and School Busing.|website=www.presidency.ucsb.edu|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref> It increased funding to the Bilingual Education Act and made additional English instruction mandatory, which effectively extended the Lau ruling to all public schools.<ref name=":0" /> The Officer for Civil Rights then developed a remedial guideline in 1975, otherwise known as the Lau Remedies, that specified methods and approaches for the school districts to follow in order to provide a meaningful education to students with limited English proficiency. This led to the development of bilingual programs and additional English instructions in most public schools.<ref>United States. Health, Education and Welfare Department. ''Task Force Findings Specifying Remedies Available for Eliminating past Educational Practices Ruled Unlawful under LAU v. NICHOLS''. N.p.: n.p., 1975. Print.</ref>
However, there have been challenges to the Lau decision in recent decades. In the Supreme Court case ''[[Alexander v. Sandoval]]'', [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 532|532]] [[United States Reports|U.S.]] 275 (2001), the Court claimed that private plaintiffs did not have the right of action to sue against disparate impact violation under Title VI and they must provide proofs of intentional discrimination. It implied that students can no longer sue schools for policies that cause disparate impact, which significantly weakened the foundation of the Lau decision.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rosenbaum|first=Sara|date=2004-01-01|title=Reducing Discrimination Affecting Persons with Limited English Proficiency: Federal Civil Rights Guidelines under Title VI of the 1964 Civil Rights Act|jstor=20056643|journal=Public Health Reports|volume=119|issue=1|pages=93–96}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 414]] * [[Bilingual education]] * [[Bilingual Education Act]] * ''[[Castañeda v. Pickard]]''
== External links == * [https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/414/563/case.html Full text of the decision]
== References == <references />
[[Category:United States Supreme Court cases]] [[Category:United States civil rights case law]] [[Category:United States education case law]] [[Category:Chinese-American history]] [[Category:Language case law]] [[Category:Linguistic rights]] [[Category:1974 in United States case law]] [[Category:1974 in education]] [[Category:Education in San Francisco]] [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases of the Burger Court]]
